areaDesc.3: Small section of high land overlooking White River. Developed into medium to large estates.
areaDesc.4: Lack of city facilities, also transportation.
areaDesc.14: Small large-estate section. Particularly popular to a certain social group. Generally find buyer available if the present owner must sell.

areaDesc.3: Site of Butler University in west portion. All city facilities.
areaDesc.4: None

5.a: Native white; executive and other white-collar type

areaDesc.14: West of Illinois Street: Influenced by Butler University. 42nd & Central: New Catholic Church and School where such families with good incomes desire their children to attend grade schools. Other section north of this, newer type houses, mostly brick veneer, built within last ten years.

areaDesc.3: Small section near small College (Indiana Central) at southern edge of the city.
areaDesc.4: Unimproved streets - distance to grade and high school. RR Tracks.
areaDesc.14: College will develop some, and increase demand. Streets will be improved and grade school facilities bettered.

areaDesc.3: Proximity to new High School, near RR shops and yards and factory districts.
areaDesc.4: Surrounding cheap territory; State Insane Hospital to the west. Grade crossing of RR and blighted district on way to City Center.
areaDesc.14: Section occupied by RR and shop men and mechanics. New High School (one only in the west side of the city) creates demand for sales and rentals in this section.

areaDesc.3: None
areaDesc.4: Age. Almost solid negro. Industrial
areaDesc.14: Blighted Area

areaDesc.3: Near Center of City. Factories for working classes.
areaDesc.4: Very old houses. RR switching yards and industry
areaDesc.14: A very old section. Spotted with factories. Tax Assesments

areaDesc.3: Proximity to Beech Grove Big 4 RR shops. Extreme southeast to Five Points, lots and tracts sufficient for gardening purposes. Luthern section with Church and School.
areaDesc.4: Lack of city facilities; transportation; number of cheap additions developed in and near this section.
areaDesc.14: Five Points: German Luteran settlement, with church and school, except for cheap addition immediately to the east which is being poorly developed because of lack of drainage. Southeastern Avenue: developed with cheap frame to good brick veneer singles. Large tracts, mostly un-platted. Section Emerson Avenue: semi-modern and modern bungalows; one-half to acre tracts unplatted. In this section a number of employees of Beech Grove Big 4 RR repair shops. live.

1.1: Indianapolis Warren Park and Shadenland Drive Section

areaDesc.3: Small suburban section, north and east of Irvington section of Indianpolis.
areaDesc.4: Lack of city facilities and distance from City Center. Part of community is developed with cheap type of houses.
areaDesc.14: Warren Park is a small separate Corporation. Development along Shadeland will be helped materially by extensions of Pleasant Run Boulevard following Pleasant Run to Shadeland AVenue adn north on Shadeland Avenue to connect with Kessler Boulevard-- part of this is now under construction. Neighborhing territory partly developed.

areaDesc.4: Cheap type houses. Lack of city facilities, transportation and schools.
areaDesc.14: Somewhat better than D-4 because of newer type of non-modern homes from laboring class of people. A small section frome ast side of Wallace to west side of Emerson and from south side of Nowland Avenue to south side of 16th partially built up-- very old cheap negro shacks.

areaDesc.4: Section of cheaper type houses bordering on good residential section. Bus transportation. Distance from City Center. Distance from high school.
areaDesc.14: Section of semi-modern and modern type houses, for mechanic and low wage white collar types. Section affected by high cost of street improvements. Will continue to develop with about the same type of contruction.

areaDesc.3: Stable neighborhood, lower Irvington and Emerson Heights Section
areaDesc.4: North part bus transportation; other portions, good transportation
areaDesc.14: Very good white-collar type section with average incomes. Along Washington Street both sides, trend is to apartments; some few business sites.

areaDesc.3: Small suburban town, incorporated. Near manufacturing plants.
areaDesc.4: Lack of proper sewage system. This is being corrected by new sewer. Limited school facilities also, which are being being corrected by additional building.
areaDesc.14: A small section not greatly affected by the depression in which prices remained very stable adn will continue to improve as city facilities in this section are bettered. Building combination single house and bungalow types.

areaDesc.4: Non-permanent homes predominate. Affected by high water of White River. Lack of city facilities.
areaDesc.14: A section built of mostly summer cottages. Used for six months of the year.

1.1: INDIANAPOLIS Mars Hill and Surrounding territory

areaDesc.3: None
areaDesc.4: Lack of city facilities. Poor transportation. Cheap class of property and citizens.
areaDesc.14: Cheap subdivision developemtns west and south-west of Indianapolis. A moderate number of good type homes scattered thru area on which local institutions will lend.

areaDesc.2: Part level; mostly rolling; few hill sections
areaDesc.3: Golf clubs. New Boulevard
areaDesc.4: Lack of transportation and city facilities. Access to center of city thru undesirable neighborhood.
areaDesc.14: Section along new Boulevard and near best Golf Club which did not develop because of high land value. Can and will be developed with small and less expensive type homes than first planned.

1.1: Indianapolis National & Rockville Road Suburban Section.

areaDesc.3: Section of moderate priced houses, not far from the City Center
areaDesc.4: Lack of city facilities. Poor transportation. Passing thru blighted area on way to City Center.
areaDesc.14: Outlying section of better class laboring and mechanic type occupancy, desiring newer design of small house. Business development, most of inferior class, along Washington (National Road) Several cheap additions, but many fairly good houses in this section.

areaDesc.3: Close to factories for working people
areaDesc.4: RR yards, Stockyards, Factories. West part affected by overflow water from Eagle Creek

5.a: Native white - Laboring and white collar classes

areaDesc.14: Section immediately around Rhodious Park developed with some newer type bungalows. Section along Blaine from McCarthy and Morris and on th other streets west to Belmont and south Howard are best parts of this section, partially developed with newer type houses. Majority are home owners. Other sections affected by very low class native whites. Section from Howard to Minnesota and from Richmond to Hiatt - negro.

areaDesc.3: Catholic churhc and school on Warman Avenue.
areaDesc.4: State Insane Hospital -- Factories, RR tracks and switching yards.
areaDesc.14: Local institutions will lend on moderate riced residences in northern section and along Warman Avenue.

areaDesc.3: Proximity to RR yards and factories where most people in this district are employed.
areaDesc.4: In center portion of district, older type of houses. Northern portion lacks good transportation.
areaDesc.14: South portion: older type, rentable and salable to better laboring class. North and west portion: newer type with foreign classes and their descendants employed as mechanics in shops and with RRs. Good demand for sale and rental when factories are operating.

areaDesc.3: Near local employment and speedway.
areaDesc.4: Lack of city facilities. Cheap construction. Small lots.
areaDesc.14: Cheap subdivision. Oversold in very small lots.

areaDesc.4: Age. RR Yards. Factories
areaDesc.14: Section north of 10th and section on Elder, Lynn and Traub north of Michigan: greater part negro, balance low standard whites.

areaDesc.4: Blighted Area
areaDesc.14: North portion from Blake to Lacke and north to Indiana recently completed low-cost apartments for negroes. There is possibility that balance of this territory west of Blake and north of Michigan may be taken over by City, County and state for development as Park, overlooking hospital development on the west.

areaDesc.2: Level to rolling, with hilly land along the River and Creek.
areaDesc.3: Number of estates develoepd particularly along Eagle Creek branches in the extreme northwest
areaDesc.4: Number of cheaper type subdivisions devleoped; lack of city facilities; lack of transportation

6.b: Frame and Br Veneer from large Bungalows

areaDesc.14: A very spotty section. Some parts in particular near Creeks and rolling land --  developed into large estates with prospect of continuing development of such types. Along Michigan Road a number of cheap subdivisions with non-modern type houses on average to large lots. Section west of Braodmoor Ave -- attempted development along new Blvd. which failed, -- somehwat over developed -- consdierable time for an active demand in this particular section. Small section called "Spring Hills, Inc." is subdivision on high land above the River, north of Ricerside Park -- an attempted likewise section in which several years ago an amount of extreme wealthy attempted to devlop into large estates, building houses from 150,000 to 300,000 with no demand for such types today. Immediately west of Riverside Park is abuilt-up section with some good and some cheaper type houses.

areaDesc.2: Level to rolling. Small restricted section known as "Golden Hill"
areaDesc.3: Small restricted section of large lots and small estate tracts
areaDesc.4: Lack of transportation, city sewer and water
areaDesc.14: Attractive location for property known as "small estates," yet not far from city center.

areaDesc.3: None
areaDesc.4: Very old -- Numerous factories.

5.a: Native wthie - Laboring and Mechanic classes

areaDesc.3: Near good section of the City and Schools
areaDesc.4: Near cemetery. Several older type houses. Number of negro families of better grade.
areaDesc.14: Narrow strip - 42nd to 43rd Sts. from Boulevard Place west: solid white section but affected by several negro families in section south of 42nd St. From Maple Road to 42nd St. a number of negro families of the better type the majority is a white neighborhood. "East: Crown Hill and 32nd St. to Maple Road and Salem Street West, a number of older type homes. Several apartments on west side, particularly Boulevard Place -- in which a few negro families reside.

areaDesc.3: South portion near best High school. good schools -- Churches of all denominations. Transportation excellent. All sections enjoy all city facilities.
areaDesc.4: South portion: number of two-family houses and four to sixteen family apartments. Section along east edge near Monon RR tracks.

6.b: Frame & Br. Veneer singles, duplexes; Br. Apartments

areaDesc.14: Section along Meridian Street: to large high class apartments. Along 28th, trend is to business and apartments. Extreme east section, along both sides of Winthrop Avenue, affected by Monon RR tracks. Along Pennsylvania Street and north of 38th: large older type good homes. Small section in extreme north east: cheaper type bungalows and some older type frame houses.

areaDesc.3: Near good schools and churches of all denominations. Short distance from City Center.
areaDesc.4: Older type houses. some very large -- used for rooming house purposes
areaDesc.14: In section from 19th to 22nd Sts and from west side of Delaware to west side of Central Ave known as "Martin's Place" - large older type well built residences, some converted into apartments and 2-fam. units, still in good rental and fair sales demand. Section from 22nd st. north to Fall Creek and from west side of park to east side of Broadway, large older type houses of fairly good construction, good rental and fair sale. Section north of Fall Creek from Penn St. east to College older type single family and 2-fam. units, still desirable rental, with fair sales demand. Section east of Fall Creek, north of 28th St. mixed 1 & 2 Fam. units, fair rental section, but very poor sales. SEction along Illinois St. -- mixed with old type one-two fam. singles, business property and apartments, fair rental but very poor sale. Balance of section mixed with large old, fine residences, to cheap older type frames, declining, except for possible development of apartments on Delaware, Pennsylvania, Central, Park and Broadway.

areaDesc.3: Portion is desirable residential neighborhood for better class negroes.
areaDesc.4: Age and inhabitants
areaDesc.13: Generally down except for better negro portion.
areaDesc.14: North of 24th St. to 29th and from west side of Capitol Ave. to Clifton (except for small section south of Roache) and west of Northwestern Ave -- a former good whtie section in whcih better class negroes now reside. However, there still remain a number of white families scattered thru this district. South of 25th, east of Northwestern and south of Roache, west of Northwestern, --  older and cheaper negro houses. Section along 29th and 30th: white neighborhood affected by negro infiltration. Section along Grayson Avenue-Capitol Avenue, also affected by negro infiltration. Section along Kenwood and Illinois -- are larger 1-2 fam. old houses occupied by lower class whites and are used partly for rooming houses. Local lending institutions will lend mortgage money to negroes of better class. Extreme northeast section is a small addition built up of very cheap houses across from Crown Hill Cemetery.

areaDesc.3: None
areaDesc.4: Poor transportation, thru blighted area to City Center. RR tracks.
areaDesc.14: South portion: majority white. North portion: East of Harding -- decided infiltration of negroes. Local institutions will make loans on better class properties in this section.

areaDesc.3: High land. Developed with larger type homes
areaDesc.4: Very old type houses becoming occupied on the east portion by negroes. New RR tracks and switching yards.
areaDesc.14: Section along Bellefountaine, Guilford and Winthrop, south of 22nd now 80% of negro. Extreme north section along McPherson-white section, mostly rentals. Number of these houses have been remodelend into cheap small apartments.

areaDesc.3: Negro Park and Municipal Golf Course.
areaDesc.4: Older type houses. RR tracks and factories. Part of section occupied by lower type negroes.
areaDesc.14: South and center portion older white neighborhood now occupied 100% by negroes. East portion cheap to fair newer type houses. Section around Douglas Park and north of 30th -- better class negroes

areaDesc.3: Near center of city
areaDesc.4: Very old. Some remodeled into cheap apartments and rooming houses. Part is factory district.
areaDesc.14: Very old section. Alleys occupied by negroes. Some factories scattered thru the district.

1.1: Indianapolis Old section near Arsenal High School.

areaDesc.3: Arsenal Techincal High School. Good Transportation. Large Catholic Church in south portion.
areaDesc.4: Very old type houses. Factories and RR tracks.
areaDesc.14: Extreme north section: negroes. Center portion: poor sale but fair rental-- near car barns and high school. South portion: large older type houses. In an old Catholic Parish

1.1: Indianapolis Woodruff Place and surrounding territory

areaDesc.3: Number of schools and churches. Good transportation-short distance-to City Center.
areaDesc.4: Older type houses. Number of 2-family units. Women's Prison affects rent and sales on Randolph and Hamilton Avenue from New York to Michigan only.
areaDesc.14: Section known as "Woodruff Place" small incorporated town. Enjoys all city facilities and police protection. This section at one time was high class residential, now being remodeled into small apartmetns and very desirable rental for that class. Section: east side of Randolph and east side of Hendrick place,-- development about 20 years old of good type singles and two family units. Good rental and fair sales. Other parts, older types and somewhat depreciated.

areaDesc.3: Largest Catholic Parish. Close to good Public High School.
areaDesc.4: Several older type houses, but mixed with majority of better type.
areaDesc.14: This section good because of desire of families of depcreciated sections to move into this part of City particularly because of High School and Church influence.

areaDesc.3: Large well developed city park and parkways along small creek. Number of grade schools and Protestant Churches.
areaDesc.4: Except fro 10th Street, -- poor transportation. Number of older type houses particularly in west end. Extreme northwest side borders on colored section.
areaDesc.14: Best residential section: from Oxford St. east to east side of Tuxedo and along south side to Brookside Parkway. Several newer type houses mixed with some of the older types; very good rental; fair saoles section; however, an over development along both sides of Brookside Park. Extreme west and northwest: older type houses; only fair rental and sales.

1.1: Indianapolis East Section near Belt RR

areaDesc.4: Near RR switching tracks; coal and lumber yards.

5.a: Native white- Laboring and white collar

areaDesc.14: Small section, eastern part of city, with many old and new type houses. Always has been fair rental, but slow sale. Affected by RR tracks.

1.1: Indianapolis Tuxedo Park and Section north

areaDesc.3: Good transportation, except in north section. Varied number of schools and churches.
areaDesc.4: Proximity to Belt RR tracks. Some small factories along said tracks. Number of older type houses from Washington to Michigan. Number of cheaper class properties in extreme north section.
areaDesc.14: Section from Michigan to 10th Street on Denny and Chester and part of Grant Street, sales and rent very active. These are the three very desirable streets in this section. Section from Washington to Michigan; older type, cottages, singles and doubles; fair sale and good rental. Extreme north section: Number of cheaply built, though quite modern, homes.

areaDesc.3: Near new Catholic Church and School; also good grade school and Protestant Churches.
areaDesc.4: Poor transportation -- bus service to downtown
areaDesc.14: Small section built around new Catholic Church and School. Very desirable to young couples of ordinary means.

areaDesc.2: Rolling, hilly. Small restricted area of larger estates
areaDesc.3: Boulevard along creek. All city facilities. Near public park. Newer development of good type house, fairly well restricted.
areaDesc.4: Section along 10th Street -- trasnportation not good and far from Schools; "Hower" School is to be built in this Section. Other parts excellent transportation and school facilities.
areaDesc.14: Best residential section east part of Indianapolis. Section along Pleasant Run Parkway, east of Emerson Avenue, developed with good type frame and brick veneer singels from new to 20 years old. All well kept. Section from Ritter east and south of 10th -- developed with frame and brick veneer bungalows and singels, from new to 15 years old. Section from 10th north of 12th Street and from Emerson Avenue to and including Hawthorne Lane, newer type frame and brick veneer bungalows. Section along north side of 10th Arlington -- not built up but next in line for eastern section of City. Section from west side of Kenmore Road to Edmondson and from Washington Street to south line of Shelby St. -- brick veneer and frame bungalows and singles. West part of which is built up nearly 100% and east part being devloped. Section east of Emerson to Pleasant Run Boulevard and from Michigan St. north to said Boulevard, 100% built up, good type frame and brick veneer singesl and bungalows from 8 to 18 years old. A very excellent sale section.

areaDesc.4: Lack of city facilities and transportation in most parts. Bordering on RR tracks.

5.a: Native white- Laboring and white- collar clerical

areaDesc.14: Small section west of Emerson between RR tracks, very poor sale and rental. Section east end of Irvington, south of Washington on Webster, Cutherwood and Sheridan, negro. Also scattered along east side Arlington Avenue. Greenfield Ave. extreme south end of Ritter and east part of Burgess Avenue, also scattered negro. Section north of Minnesota on both ways from Emerson, built up chiefly with non-modern cheap houses

areaDesc.3: Older but good section of former fine residential section of Irvington. New stores, churches and schools.
areaDesc.4: Several large older type houses.
areaDesc.14: Good old section of Irvington. A former very good residential suburb. Older -- but good single houses mixed with two-family doubles more recently constructed. Along Washington Street: apartments, business and family units.

areaDesc.3: Close to City Center
areaDesc.4: Lack of city facilities in most of territory. Poor transportation. RR grade crossing at Madison Avenue on way to reach City Center.
areaDesc.14: Section developed with small semi-modern and modern type houses-- section only partially developed, bordered by good and cheaper sections. Considerable spotty possible development along Madison Avenue not of good type which affects the entire neighborhood.

areaDesc.3: Near factories and shops for laboring and mechanic classes.
areaDesc.4: Lack of transportation in most part. Near RR tracks
areaDesc.14: Four negro sections: one west from Sherman Drive and south of Prospect-- heavy. Extreme west end from Lawton to Calhoun, Shelly to Draper. From Keystone to St. Paul, north of Woodlawn and along Pleasant Street-- scattered. East of Keystone to Perkins from Reformers Avenue to RR tracks -- heavy. Section bordering Southeastern Avenue from Trowbridge east to LaSalle -- mortgage money for home purchase available from local institutions.

1.1: Indianapolis Section East of Fountain Square

areaDesc.3: Short distance to City Center. Number of Churches: several Protestant--2 Lutheran and schools, and one Catholic and school.
areaDesc.4: Older type houses
areaDesc.14: Section occupied by mechanics and white collar type and also business men having stores within a short distance. Desirable section also for laboring and RR type of employee. In extreme southeast section number of newer type modern small bungalows.

areaDesc.3: Number of older German Type citizens near Lutheran Churches and Schools.
areaDesc.4: Older type houses; bordered by cheaper old class -- thru very old part of city to City Center
areaDesc.14: Old but good section. Nearly all home owners of German Lutheran type, desiring to be near to their Churches and Schools.

areaDesc.3: North portion, large German Catholic Church. South portion, number of newer type houses. Good school and Protestant Churches.
areaDesc.4: North section: older type houses. South section: factories along belt RR and grade crossing of two RR tracks.
areaDesc.14: North portion: Number of German Catholic families willing to maintain residences near large Catholic Church. South portion: Somewhat improved by development of Boulevard at Pleasant Run and elevation of Belt RR at Meridian Street recently completed.

areaDesc.3: Near Large Park. Good Transportation. Good grade of schools. Several Protestant and one Catholic Church and School.
areaDesc.4: Bordered by cheaper and older sections. Grade crossing - RR Tracks - to city Center.
areaDesc.13: Will remain good for several years
areaDesc.14: Section of south of Southern Avenue, newer type frame and brick veneer singles and bungalows in demand. Mechanics to white-collar type. Section east of Garfield Park to Shelby Street, and south of Raymond is beste residential section of South Side. Neighborhood business and professional men. Section east of Shelby Street around Catholic Church. Mostly mechanics. In thru this part are scattered about ten negro families -- better class, all home owners. West of Garfield Park not fully built up being developed with frame and semi-modern and modern bungalows -- mechanics and white collar type occupancy.

1.1: INDIANAPOLIS Older part of South Side

areaDesc.3: None
areaDesc.4: Very old especially in northern portion. Factories and RR tracks. Cheap construction in southern portion.

areaDesc.3: Fairly close-in section from truck gardens and greenhouses.
areaDesc.4: Poor transportation and lack of city facilities. Cheap additions developed in this area.
areaDesc.14: Section developed mostly by gardeners with vegetable and flower greenhouses. Above sales and rental ranges do not include greenhouses which represent additional investments of from $7000 to $25000. The low grade additions in the area are shown in RED. Section west of the I.C. RR. : low and subject to high water

1.1: INDIANAPOLIS St. Rock German Catholic Church Section

areaDesc.3: New German-Catholic Church and School (Branch of large old German -Catholic Parish) Not far from City Center
areaDesc.4: Lack of city facililties and improved streets
areaDesc.14: Section being developed by younger citizens of German descent, will greatly improve during the next several years. Large lots to acreage tracts. Number of truck green houses scattered thruout the section

areaDesc.3: Large city Park. Number of Protestant Churches. One Catholic Church and School.
areaDesc.4: Distance from transportation in east portion and several negro families. In west portion, several oldertype houses.
areaDesc.14: Influence of Garfield Park, Churches, etc. in this section creates a good demand for mechanic and laboring classes, as well as lower bracket of white-collar class.

areaDesc.3: Near city Park and factories. Fairly good transportation.
areaDesc.4: Older type houses. Near RR tracks.

5.a: Native White - Laboring and white collar

areaDesc.14: Section developed in teh cheap-to-fair houses. Desirable for laboring classes.

1.1: Indianapolis Churchman Avenue and outlying sections.

areaDesc.3: Proximity to RR shops at Beech Grove-- near factory district in southeast Indianapolis.
areaDesc.4: Lack of complete city facilities in most of this territory. Poor transportation.
areaDesc.14: Section developed with cheap to fair type houses on small lots to acre tracts for mechanic and laboring classes. Golf course shown on plat has no influences on the section.

areaDesc.2: Flat terrain. Contiguous to Indianapolis on the south. Inhabited chiefly by employees of CCC, St. Louis RR shops.
areaDesc.3: Convenience to emplyment in RR shops
areaDesc.4: One industry
areaDesc.13: Static -- depending no employment in RR shops
areaDesc.14: Best part of RR shop district. Excellent rental and sale section of small houses when RR shops are in operation.

areaDesc.3: Adjacence to Big Four RR shops
areaDesc.4: Poor transportation. Lack of city facilities in most parts.
areaDesc.14: East part of Beech Grove, older type non-modern houses close to RR shops. Other part of this section, sparsely built up with cheap to fair type single family homes. Morgage money is available in this territory from local institutions.

areaDesc.3: Suburban section not far from city center. Good transportation.
areaDesc.4: Lack of city facilities --  number of cheaper type houses. Few restrictions in most additions.
areaDesc.14: Section not far out, where working men and mechanics can have small additional ground for gardening purposes in additon to homes. A number of very good frame and brick veneer homes in this section. Most purchasers buy or build non-modern homes and imporve and modernize as finances permit.

areaDesc.3: Fairly close in suburban development
areaDesc.4: Lack of transportation and city facilities
areaDesc.14: This territory developed from cehap houses to good small estates. In a number of cases-over-development.

areaDesc.3: None
areaDesc.4: Partially developed near RR shops and yards and factories. Lack of city facilities and transportation.
areaDesc.14: Developed with cheapertype houses--now non-modern type. When sold, are on very low payments

areaDesc.3: Close to factories, RR shops and yards.
areaDesc.4: Older type houses. Poor transportation.
areaDesc.13: Only for laboring class and RR mechanics.
areaDesc.14: Formerly residence fo employee of Big 4 RR shops which were mostly moved to Beech Grove about 20 years ago. North of 28th Street from LaSalle to Forest Manor: enwer type 1-2 fam. bungalows, desirable for rental and home purchase by laboring and mechanic types. Section from 25th south to Roosevelt Avenue from LaSalle to Olney-- older type houses, occupied by better class RR men and local business men. Section from Roosevelt Avenue north, east to Tacoma and along line of Ludlow Avenue, occupied by better class laboring people and mechanics. Those three sections have avilability of mortgage funds for home purchase from local institutions. Section along Massachusetts Avenue facing RR tracks-- occupied mostly by negroes.

1.1: INDIANAPOLIS Northeast Park and Forest Manor Section

areaDesc.3: Moderate priced homes for working class and mechinic types, along 38th. West part recently taken into City with new grade school.
areaDesc.4: North section is known as "Brightwood" section. Distance from Center of City. Lack of city facilities. Possible heavy street improvement.
areaDesc.14: Suburban section, west part of which was recently taken into city limits. Section east of Sherman Drive to Arthington, known as "Forest Manor", part wooded lots and sparsely developed with brick veneer type of home. New highway, widening 38th Street and new bridge crossing Fall Creek at 38th Street gives access to downtown section without driving, as formerly thru a blighted area.

1.1: INDIANAPOLIS Suburban - Northeast Pendleton Pike Section and north of 38th Street

areaDesc.3: Interurban service. Large lots to acre tracts. New highway developed on 38th St.
areaDesc.4: Lack of city facilities. Several cheaper type properties.
areaDesc.14: Moderate price suburban section occupied by working class. Large lots. Will continue to develop about the same type of home in the future

areaDesc.4: Unimproved streets. Older type houses. Lack of city facilities in most streets. Distance from transportation.
areaDesc.14: Older part of a former separate Corporation, now a part of Indianapolis. Only attraction is as residence for servants to residents of better class suburban development further north.

areaDesc.3: Small section, sparsely developed with fair-to-good type frame and brick veneer bugalows. Near new high school.
areaDesc.4: Distance from center of city -- lack of city facilities on all streets
areaDesc.14: City facilities will be put in balance of this section, and will be developed with about the same type as has been in the past.

areaDesc.2: Partly level, partly rolling. All high ground, only partially developed. Section to become best residential part of the city
areaDesc.3: Large lots -- some well wooded. Very highly restricted.
areaDesc.4: Lack of sewers, city water and transportation
areaDesc.14: A section of high land north of White River, well platted. Mostly small estate type lots. Will be future best residential section

areaDesc.4: Subject to overflow of River. Majority summer residents. Lack of city facilities. Distance from transportation.
areaDesc.14: A summer residential section. Developed in part by few cheap and some fair permanent residences.

1.1: INDIANAPOLIS Northeast Suburban: Braodripple, Allisonville Millersville

areaDesc.3: Topography
areaDesc.4: Lack of city facilities and transportation
areaDesc.14: Section along Allisonville Road and Millersville Road -- developed with some good brick veneer singles. Several small additions scattered thru this section with cheaper type houses. Towns of Millersville, Castleton and Allisonville vary -- old cross-roads towns -- with cheap old style houses.

areaDesc.3: Hihgly restricted subdivision. Large estate tracts with forests, trees and shrubery.
areaDesc.4: Lack of transportation and city facilities. Distance from city center and distance from good highways to reach city center.
areaDesc.14: A highly restricted subdivision. On the market for several years in which the original owner attempted to control the purchasers. This and lack of access to the City affected development. However, new Boulevard along west bank of Fall Creek from city limits is now being constructed which will help this section very materially.

areaDesc.3: Small section developed with mdoerate priced homes bordering on teh best residential section
areaDesc.4: Previous floods. Lack of city sewers. Unimproved sterets. Distance from schools
areaDesc.14: Section was affected by flood seepage; this has been improved by widening and straightening the channel of the White River. Will be further corrected by new sewer on whcih construction will start this year. There will be no assessment for this against the property.

1.1: INDIANAPOLIS North Indianapolis and Riverside Park

areaDesc.3: West section borders on largest park and golf course. North section: very good type of citizenry
areaDesc.4: Encroachment of inharmonious groups (negro). Necessity of travel thru blighted section to reach City Center. Distance from educational centers, particularly High Schools

6.c: North section: 25 years West Section: 18 years

areaDesc.13: Not good in north section; fair-to-good in west.
areaDesc.14: North section nearly 100% built up -- older type houses with bungalows intermingling. Possibility of negro purchasers from territory south of 30th street. West section not fully developed -- newer type frame bungalows; will probably remain stable for several years with some new building.

1.1: INDIANAPOLIS Christian Park and South Irvington Section

areaDesc.3: In west section development is newer type semi and modern bungalows for wokring-men types. Good trasnportation, near Washington Street - business district.
areaDesc.4: Lack of complete city facilities in extreme south of west portion. Lack of good transportation except Washington St. Number of older type houses in east portion. Small negro development in south portion; also negro influence in extreme northeast section and center Irvington section.

6.c: Christian Park Sec. 18 yrs. Irvington Sec. 30 yrs

areaDesc.13: Christian Pk. Sec. Slightly increasing; South Irvington Sec. Static.
areaDesc.14: New Boulevard along Pleasant Run Parkway and around Christian Park helping to develop that particular neighborhood. South Irvington section affected by cheaper type houses and extreme older type residences; future - static.
